results.title: No. 1 hits of the 60's (1960-1965)
results.creator_credit: Cable Connections and Cyriel Van Den Heme
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rock n’ roll: the greatest years”.
This tape provides a nostalgic compilation of classics from the era, smattered with a healthy dose of gossip surrounding the performers. Songs on the tape include: “Stars on 45”, Stars on 45: “Only the lonely”, Roy Orbison: “Walk right back”, Everly Brothers: “The Young ones”, Cliff Richard: “Diamonds”, Jet Harris: “I Like it”, Gerry & the Pacemakers: “Do you love me?”, Brian Poole & Tremeloes: “Needles & pins”, Searchers: “World without love”, Peter & Gordon: “Juliet”, Four Pennies: “House of the rising sun”, Animals: “Have I the right”, Honeycombes: “You really got me”, Kinks: “I’m into something good”, Hermans Hermits: “Oh pretty woman”, Roy Orbison: “Go now”, Moody Blues: “You’ve lost that loving feeling”, Righteous Brothers: “I’m alive”, The Hollies.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cable Connections and Cyriel Van Den Heme

results.title: Serving food
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Army
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Hospital food service personnel training”.
Emphasises principles of food preparation and service in hospitals - proper temperature, correct quality, selection of food to meet patient’s requirements, and courteous attention buy food service personnel.

Episode number 3 of Series “Hospital food service personnel training”.
Instructions on how to clean kitchen equipment; loosen, dissolve and emulsify dirt; rinse and dry equipment; and prevent food poisoning.

results.title: The Individual
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Army
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Hospital food service personnel training”.
Instructions in methods of preventing communicable diseases associated with improper food handling. Illustrates habits that should be avoided by cooks and waitresses including dirty clothes and hands, untidy hair, and handling of the eating surface of crockery and cutlery.

results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Hospital food service personnel training”.
Introduces some main features of hospital food organisation: varied deparments, their equipment, and the over-all system of menu planning. Shows the general arrangements of food preparation used in hospitals.

results.title: The Century of cinema
results.creator_credit: British Film Institute and Channel Four
results.brief_description: ‘The Century of cinema’ is a series of highly personal documentaries made by leading film directors throughout the world. It was executive produced by Colin MacCabe and Bob Last for BFI TV and Channel Four Television in association with a world-wide alliance of broadcasters and distributors.

results.title: The Century of cinema: Russia and Poland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
The Russian Idea (Producers, Leonid Vereschagin, Valery Ruzin, director, Sergei Selyanov): Philosopher Nikolai Berdyaev asserted that the Russian cinema consisted of a series of opposing forces - despotism and anarchy, cruelty and kindness, mysticism and atheism, servitude and riot. In an attempt to reach beyond their contradictory nature, the Russian people would create perfect worlds attainable only through the destruction of dissonant reality. The desire for revolution has been termed ‘The Russian Idea’. In this controversial documentary, Sergei Selyanov seeks evidence of this ‘idea’ in Russian cinema. Beginning with an extensive depiction of the social Utopianism of Twenties Russia, fragments of films are juxtaposed alongside each other in order to reflect hopeful and fantastic pictures of a bright new future. In contrast to this is the realistic atmosphere of Moscow depicted in Boris Barnet’s films and their images of the struggles that people were willing to endure in order to realise their utopian ideals. Selyanov believes that in the Thirties ‘The Russian Idea’ degenerated on the screen into the ugly official Utopia of Stalinism - a theme which permeated everything until Krushchev came to power, when cinema gradually returned to the sources and depths of the national character. “100 years of Polish cinema” (Producers, Ryszard Sraszewski, Krzysztof Kieslowski, Irena Strzalkowska, director, Pawel Lozinski): Based on an original idea by Krzysztof Kieslowski, Pawel Lozinski’s documentary differs from other films in the Century of Cinema series in its unique approach to cinema as perceived by the audience. In interviews with a dramatic range of individuals - children, the elderly, the visually impaired - Lozinski attempts to evoke the magic and power of Polish cinema through collective memory. Through these personal monologues it is possible to see what has moved a Polish audience over the past century. There are no filmmakers interviewed in this documentary, no technicians or critics or financiers - simply those for whom the movies are made. In Polish in with English subtitles.

results.title: 2 x 50 Years of French cinema: night of the filmmakers: I am curious, film
results.creator_credit: Anne-Marie Mieville, Edgar Reitz, Jean-Luc Godard, Stig Bjorkman, Lennart Dunner, Robert Busch, British Film Institute and Channel Four
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
2x50 years of French cinema (52 mins, 1995) ‘Why celebrate cinema? Isn’t it famous already?’: Jean-Luc Godard confronts actor Michel Piccoli, president of France’s First Century of Cinema Association with his theory that French cinema has been forgotten, that he and Mieville are making a film about a century of French cinema that will be a chronicle of forgetting. Piccoli puts this theory to the test with the staff of the hotel where he is staying and is dismayed to find barely any recognition of names from French film history or even classic movies such as ‘La regle du jeu’. Set in Munich, in a magnificent new Kinemathek opened to celebrate the first century of cinema, ‘Night of the Filmmakers’ (54 mins, 1994) imagines an assembly of German filmmakers such that only the artifice of film could bring together, attempting to find answers to questions such as, what exactly makes a German film German? How much was lost to German cinema with all the talent fleeing the Nazi regime? What was the effect on film-making on the Berlin Wall? Includes interviews with Volker Schlondorff, Helma Sanders-Brahms, Werner Herzog, Wim Wenders, Frank Beyer and Wolfgang Kohlhasse. Actress Hanna Schygulla reminisces about Rainer Werner Fassbinder. In ‘I am curious, film’ (52 mins, 1995) actress Lena Nyman is Bjoerkman’s guide on a journey through Nordic cinema history, attempting to discover the special elements of Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, Finnish and Icelandic cinema. Her journey is richly illustrated with film clips and includes conversations with filmmakers such as Lars von Trier, Stefan Jarl, Liv Ullman and Aki Kaurismaki. In French, German, Danish with English subtitles - some sections in English.
results.title_for_label: 2 x 50 Years of French cinema: night of the filmmakers: I am curious, film

Set in Munich, in a magnificent new Kinemathek opened to celebrate the first century of cinema, ‘Night of the Filmmakers’ (54 mins, 1994) imagines an assembly of German filmmakers such that only the artifice of film could bring together, attempting to find answers to questions such as, what exactly makes a German film German? How much was lost to German cinema with all the talent fleeing the Nazi regime? What was the effect on film-making on the Berlin Wall? Includes interviews with Volker Schlondorff, Helma Sanders-Brahms, Werner Herzog, Wim Wenders, Frank Beyer and Wolfgang Kohlhasse. Actress Hanna Schygulla reminisces about Rainer Werner Fassbinder. In ‘I am curious, film’ (52 mins, 1995) actress Lena Nyman is Bjoerkman’s guide on a journey through Nordic cinema history, attempting to discover the special elements of Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, Finnish and Icelandic cinema. Her journey is richly illustrated with film clips and includes conversations with filmmakers such as Lars von Trier, Stefan Jarl, Liv Ullman and Aki Kaurismaki. In French, German, Danish with English subtitles - some sections in English.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
2x50 years of French cinema (52 mins, 1995) ‘Why celebrate cinema? Isn’t it famous already?’: Jean-Luc Godard confronts actor Michel Piccoli, president of France’s First Century of Cinema Association with his theory that French cinema has been forgotten, that he and Mieville are making a film about a century of French cinema that will be a chronicle of forgetting. Piccoli puts this theory to the test with the staff of the hotel where he is staying and is dismayed to find barely any recognition of names from French film history or even classic movies such as ‘La regle du jeu’. Set in Munich, in a magnificent new Kinemathek opened to celebrate the first century of cinema, ‘Night of the Filmmakers’ (54 mins, 1994) imagines an assembly of German filmmakers such that only the artifice of film could bring together, attempting to find answers to questions such as, what exactly makes a German film German? How much was lost to German cinema with all the talent fleeing the Nazi regime? What was the effect on film-making on the Berlin Wall? Includes interviews with Volker Schlondorff, Helma Sanders-Brahms, Werner Herzog, Wim Wenders, Frank Beyer and Wolfgang Kohlhasse. Actress Hanna Schygulla reminisces about Rainer Werner Fassbinder. In ‘I am curious, film’ (52 mins, 1995) actress Lena Nyman is Bjoerkman’s guide on a journey through Nordic cinema history, attempting to discover the special elements of Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, Finnish and Icelandic cinema. Her journey is richly illustrated with film clips and includes conversations with filmmakers such as Lars von Trier, Stefan Jarl, Liv Ullman and Aki Kaurismaki. In French, German, Danish with English subtitles - some sections in English.
